entry.et: Middle English, from Old English trēow; akin to Old Norse trē tree, Greek drys, Sanskrit dāru wood

def.dt: :a woody perennial plant having a single usually elongate main stem generally with few or no branches on its lower part
:a shrub or herb of arborescent form rose trees a banana tree
:a piece of wood (as a post or pole) usually adapted to a particular use or forming part of a structure or implement
:the cross on which Jesus was crucified
:gallows
:something in the form of or resembling a tree: as
:a diagram or graph that branches usually from a simple stem or vertex without forming loops or polygons a genealogical tree phylogenetic trees
:a much-branched system of channels especially in an animal body the vascular tree
:saddletree
:to drive to or up a tree treed by a bull dogs treeing game
:to put into a position of extreme disadvantage :corner
:to bring to bay
:to furnish or fit (as a shoe) with a tree
Sir Herbert (Draper) Beerbohm 1853–1917 Eng. actor-manager
:wood ear
:an area of forest land managed to ensure continuous commercial production
:any of various ferns (especially families Cyatheaceae and Dicksoniaceae) of arborescent habit with a woody stem
:any of numerous small anuran amphibians (especially family Hylidae) of usually arboreal habits that typically have adhesive disks on the toes
:a structure (as a playhouse) built among the branches of a tree
:environmentalist 2
:an advocate for the preservation of woodlands
:timberline
